data: {"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3139733,"name":"Elliot Scher","username":"Gandagorn","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gandagorn/{size}/267112_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-04T21:56:21.400Z","cooked":"\u003cp\u003eSo our team has a wrist mechanism that we want to put on our robot this year. We have it to where we can make it go to a specific position, like straight up or down or sticking straight out. The problem arises when we add weight. The spark max brake mode can’t hold up what we need to hold up without running the motor. So my question is if there is a way to calculate at runtime, how much power to supply the motor with for the wrist to hold up our Coleman","username":"beanrhit","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/b/48db29/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-02-04T23:19:27.909Z","cooked":"\u003cp\u003eWe have had this issue before and for some things we use a ball shifting gearbox(or parts thereof) with the second gear tied to a fixed position (usually a whole broached in a plat for a half inch axel).  You run the wrist or elevator to a specific position one one gear in the shifting gearbox and fire the the shift to lock the gearbox to the other gear that is locked in place then that keeps you from moving at all.  We use this to lock elevators in place but had to switch to a larger diameter piston to have enough pressure to hold the elevator in place with heavy loads.\u003c/p\u003e","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":36,"updated_at":"2023-02-04T23:21:05.490Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":564,"readers_count":563,"score":122.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":425787,"topic_slug":"holding-up-a-wrist-with-a-neo","display_username":"Jeff Coleman","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":38273,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/holding-up-a-wrist-with-a-neo/425787/6","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3139790,"name":"Elliot Scher","username":"Gandagorn","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gandagorn/{size}/267112_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-04T23:26:00.146Z","cooked":"\u003cp\u003eIdeally, because we don’t have a shifting gearbox, we’d like to do this all in software. Is it possible to do this with a combination of feedforward and pid control?\u003c/p\u003e","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":36,"updated_at":"2023-02-04T23:26:00.146Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":511,"readers_count":510,"score":112.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":425787,"topic_slug":"holding-up-a-wrist-with-a-neo","display_username":"Elliot Scher","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":38273,"username":"beanrhit","name":"Jeff Coleman","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/b/48db29/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":49423,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2815A (19-23) | 190M (23...)"},"post_url":"/t/holding-up-a-wrist-with-a-neo/425787/7","custom_user_title":"2815A (19-23) | 190M (23...)","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3139804,"name":"Elliot Scher","username":"Gandagorn","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gandagorn/{size}/267112_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-05T00:02:52.666Z","cooked":"\u003cp\u003eIf I want to hold the arm up, the desired velocity should be 0 correct? When the arm falls, it has a negative velocity so would the feedforward work if I set the velocity to 0? Or would the feedforward think I want to just let the arm fall?\u003c/p\u003e","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":36,"updated_at":"2023-02-05T00:02:52.666Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":7,"reads":480,"readers_count":479,"score":141.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":425787,"topic_slug":"holding-up-a-wrist-with-a-neo","display_username":"Elliot Scher","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":12381,"username":"Oblarg","name":"Eli Barnett","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/oblarg/{size}/161674_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":49423,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2815A (19-23) | 190M (23...)"},"post_url":"/t/holding-up-a-wrist-with-a-neo/425787/8","custom_user_title":"2815A (19-23) | 190M (23...)","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3139807,"name":"Kaleb Dodd","username":"Kaleb_Dodd","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kaleb_dodd/{size}/7859_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-05T00:09:30.665Z","cooked":"\u003cp\u003eYou don’t want a feed forward based on velocity, but instead have it change based on the angle the arm/wrist is at. ugc\"\u003eoverload\u003c/a\u003e of \u003ccode\u003emotor.getPidController().setReference\u003c/code\u003e, you can add an arbitrary FF term on top of the feedback Reeve","username":"kreeve","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kreeve/{size}/187015_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-05T00:35:51.603Z","cooked":"\u003cp\u003eYou’ll want to use the angle of the wrist with respect to the ground, something like \u003ccode\u003esomeConstant * cos(theta)\u003c/code\u003e. This is basically what \u003ca href=\"https://github.wpilib.org/allwpilib/docs/release/java/edu/wpi/first/math/controller/ArmFeedforward.html\" rel=\"noopener nofollow ugc\"\u003eArmFeedforward\u003c/a\u003e does. The angle \u003ccode\u003etheta\u003c/code\u003e is the angle between the wrist and the ground, you can calculate it by setting an appropriate position conversion factor (\u003ccode\u003esparkMax.getEncoder().setPositionConversionFactor\u003c/code\u003e) at construction time, and then call \u003ccode\u003esparkMax.getEncoder().getPosition()\u003c/code\u003e to get the current position in degrees or radians. The constant \u003ccode\u003ekg\u003c/code\u003e in \u003ccode\u003eArmFeedforward\u003c/code\u003e can be found with some fancy modeling, or you can just experiment a bit to find a good value.\u003c/p\u003e","post_number":13,"post_type":1,"posts_count":36,"updated_at":"2023-02-05T00:35:51.603Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":12,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":5,"reads":428,"readers_count":427,"score":160.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":425787,"topic_slug":"holding-up-a-wrist-with-a-neo","display_username":"Kyle gyroscope to find the angle? Could I just use the position of the motor’s encoder and map the rotations to radian values?\u003c/p\u003e","post_number":14,"post_type":1,"posts_count":36,"updated_at":"2023-02-05T00:42:53.398Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":13,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":408,"readers_count":407,"score":121.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":425787,"topic_slug":"holding-up-a-wrist-with-a-neo","display_username":"Elliot Scher","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":10385,"username":"kreeve","name":"Kyle Reeve","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kreeve/{size}/187015_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":49423,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2815A (19-23) | 190M (23...)"},"post_url":"/t/holding-up-a-wrist-with-a-neo/425787/14","custom_user_title":"2815A (19-23) | 190M (23...)","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3139829,"name":"Kyle Reeve","username":"kreeve","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kreeve/{size}/187015_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-05T00:48:52.323Z","cooked":"\u003cp\u003eNo need for a gyro (not really practical to put one on a wrist), just use the built in encoder on the NEO. As long as you make sure to start the wrist in the same position each time you start the robot, you should be able to map the NEO encoder’s position to an angle in radians or degrees.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe easiest way to figure that out is:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003col\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eStart the robot with the wrist in a known position. We’ll call this \u003ccode\u003estartAngle\u003c/code\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eIn your code, put the value of \u003ccode\u003emotor.getEncoder().getPosition()\u003c/code\u003e on SmartDashboard\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eMove the wrist to a known angle (maybe 90 degrees). We’ll call this \u003ccode\u003eendAngle\u003c/code\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eRecord the value of \u003ccode\u003egetPosition()\u003c/code\u003e at \u003ccode\u003eendAngle\u003c/code\u003e, and use that to set the position conversion factor \u003ccode\u003emotor.getEncoder().setPositionConversionFactor((endAngle - startAngle) / valueAtEndAngle)\u003c/code\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf you do that, then \u003ccode\u003egetPosition()\u003c/code\u003e will from now on give you an angle in degrees\u003c/p\u003e","post_number":15,"post_type":1,"posts_count":36,"updated_at":"2023-02-05T00:48:52.323Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":14,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":410,"readers_count":409,"score":112.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":425787,"topic_slug":"holding-up-a-wrist-with-a-neo","display_username":"Kyle Reeve","username":"kreeve","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kreeve/{size}/187015_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-05T00:57:44.429Z","cooked":"\u003cp\u003eYeah, just put the angle into the \u003ccode\u003eArmFeedforward.calculate\u003c/code\u003e method. Something like\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cpre\u003e\u003ccode class=\"lang-auto\"\u003eprivate ArmFeedforward armFeedforward = new ArmFeedforward(ks, kg, 0);\n\n...\n// In constructor\npublic Wrist() {\n motor.getEncoder().setPositionConversionFactor((endAngle - startAngle) / valueAtEndAngle);\n}\n\n...\npublic void setAngle(Rotation2d angle) {\n // Here I'm not using the `kv` part of ArmFeedforward, just letting built in PID do the rest\n  motor.getPidController().setReference(angle.getRadians(), 0, armFeedforward.calculate(angle.getRadians(), 0));\n// This is assuming your position conversion is configured to return radians\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e","post_number":17,"post_type":1,"posts_count":36,"updated_at":"2023-02-05T00:57:44.429Z","reply_count":4,"reply_to_post_number":16,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":10,"reads":391,"readers_count":390,"score":193.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":425787,"topic_slug":"holding-up-a-wrist-with-a-neo","display_username":"Kyle
